trans-unit.source: Tutorial: Create a pipeline with Copy Activity using Data Factory Editor
trans-unit.target: Tutorial: Create a pipeline with Copy Activity using Data Factory Editor

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will create an Azure Data Factory pipeline with a Copy Activity by using the Data Factory Editor in the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will create an Azure Data Factory pipeline with a Copy Activity by using the Data Factory Editor in the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: Tutorial: Create a pipeline with Copy Activity using Data Factory Editor
trans-unit.target: Tutorial: Create a pipeline with Copy Activity using Data Factory Editor

trans-unit.source: In This Tutorial
trans-unit.target: In This Tutorial

trans-unit.source: This tutorial contains the following steps:
trans-unit.target: This tutorial contains the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Step
trans-unit.target: Step

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Step 1: Create an Azure Data Factory</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Step 1: Create an Azure Data Factory</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will create an Azure data factory named ADFTutorialDataFactory.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will create an Azure data factory named ADFTutorialDataFactory.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Step 2: Create linked services</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Step 2: Create linked services</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will create two linked services: StorageLinkedService and AzureSqlLinkedService.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will create two linked services: StorageLinkedService and AzureSqlLinkedService.

trans-unit.source: The StorageLinkedService links the Azure storage and AzureSqlLinkedService links the Azure SQL database to the ADFTutorialDataFactory.
trans-unit.target: The StorageLinkedService links the Azure storage and AzureSqlLinkedService links the Azure SQL database to the ADFTutorialDataFactory.

trans-unit.source: The input data for the pipeline resides in a blob container in the Azure blob storage and output data will be stored in a table in the Azure SQL database.
trans-unit.target: The input data for the pipeline resides in a blob container in the Azure blob storage and output data will be stored in a table in the Azure SQL database.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, you add these two data stores as linked services to the data factory.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, you add these two data stores as linked services to the data factory.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Step 3: Create input and output tables</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Step 3: Create input and output tables</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: In the previous step, you created linked services that refer to data stores that contain input/output data.
trans-unit.target: In the previous step, you created linked services that refer to data stores that contain input/output data.

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will define two data factory tables -- EmpTableFromBlob and EmpSQLTable -- that represent the input/output data that is stored in the data stores.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will define two data factory tables -- EmpTableFromBlob and EmpSQLTable -- that represent the input/output data that is stored in the data stores.

trans-unit.source: For the EmpTableFromBlob, you will specify the blob container that contains a blob with the source data and for the EmpSQLTable, you will specify the SQL table that will store the output data.
trans-unit.target: For the EmpTableFromBlob, you will specify the blob container that contains a blob with the source data and for the EmpSQLTable, you will specify the SQL table that will store the output data.

trans-unit.source: You will also specify other properties such as structure of the data, availability of the data, etc...
trans-unit.target: You will also specify other properties such as structure of the data, availability of the data, etc...

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Step 4: Create and run a pipeline</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Step 4: Create and run a pipeline</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will create a pipeline named ADFTutorialPipeline in the ADFTutorialDataFactory.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will create a pipeline named ADFTutorialPipeline in the ADFTutorialDataFactory.

trans-unit.source: The pipeline will have a Copy Activity that copies input data from the Azure blob to the output Azure SQL table.
trans-unit.target: The pipeline will have a Copy Activity that copies input data from the Azure blob to the output Azure SQL table.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Step 5: Monitor slices and pipeline</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Step 5: Monitor slices and pipeline</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will monitor slices of input and output tables by using Azure Preview Portal.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will monitor slices of input and output tables by using Azure Preview Portal.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 1: Create an Azure Data Factory
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 1: Create an Azure Data Factory

trans-unit.source: In this step, you use the Azure Preview Portal to create an Azure data factory named ADFTutorialDataFactory.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you use the Azure Preview Portal to create an Azure data factory named ADFTutorialDataFactory.

trans-unit.source: After logging into the Azure Preview Portal[azure-preview-portal], click NEW from the bottom-left corner, select Data analytics in the Create blade, and click Data Factory in the Data analytics blade.
trans-unit.target: After logging into the Azure Preview Portal[azure-preview-portal], click NEW from the bottom-left corner, select Data analytics in the Create blade, and click Data Factory in the Data analytics blade.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New->DataFactory</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New->DataFactory</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the New data factory blade:
trans-unit.target: In the New data factory blade:

trans-unit.source: Enter ADFTutorialDataFactory for the name.
trans-unit.target: Enter ADFTutorialDataFactory for the name.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New data factory blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New data factory blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click RESOURCE GROUP NAME and do the following:
trans-unit.target: Click RESOURCE GROUP NAME and do the following:

trans-unit.source: Click Create a new resource group.
trans-unit.target: Click Create a new resource group.

trans-unit.source: In the Create resource group blade, enter ADFTutorialResourceGroup for the name of the resource group, and click OK.
trans-unit.target: In the Create resource group blade, enter ADFTutorialResourceGroup for the name of the resource group, and click OK.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create Resource Group</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create Resource Group</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Some of the steps in this tutorial assume that you use the name: ADFTutorialResourceGroup for the resource group.
trans-unit.target: Some of the steps in this tutorial assume that you use the name: ADFTutorialResourceGroup for the resource group.

trans-unit.source: To learn about resource groups, see <link><linkText>Using resource groups to manage your Azure resources</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To learn about resource groups, see <link><linkText>Using resource groups to manage your Azure resources</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In the New data factory blade, notice that Add to Startboard is selected.
trans-unit.target: In the New data factory blade, notice that Add to Startboard is selected.

trans-unit.source: Click Create in the New data factory blade.
trans-unit.target: Click Create in the New data factory blade.

trans-unit.source: The name of the Azure data factory must be globally unique.
trans-unit.target: The name of the Azure data factory must be globally unique.

trans-unit.source: If you receive the error: Data factory name “ADFTutorialDataFactory” is not available, change the name of the data factory (for example, yournameADFTutorialDataFactory) and try creating again.
trans-unit.target: If you receive the error: Data factory name “ADFTutorialDataFactory” is not available, change the name of the data factory (for example, yournameADFTutorialDataFactory) and try creating again.

trans-unit.source: Use this name in place of ADFTutorialFactory while performing remaining steps in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Use this name in place of ADFTutorialFactory while performing remaining steps in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Data Factory - Naming Rules[data-factory-naming-rules]</linkText><title></title></link> topic for naming rules for Data Factory artifacts.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Data Factory - Naming Rules[data-factory-naming-rules]</linkText><title></title></link> topic for naming rules for Data Factory artifacts.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Data Factory name not available</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Data Factory name not available</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click NOTIFICATIONS hub on the left and look for notifications from the creation process.
trans-unit.target: Click NOTIFICATIONS hub on the left and look for notifications from the creation process.

trans-unit.source: Click X to close the NOTIFICATIONS blade if it is open.
trans-unit.target: Click X to close the NOTIFICATIONS blade if it is open.

trans-unit.source: After the creation is complete, you will see the DATA FACTORY blade as shown below.
trans-unit.target: After the creation is complete, you will see the DATA FACTORY blade as shown below.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Data factory home page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Data factory home page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 2: Create linked services
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 2: Create linked services

trans-unit.source: Linked services link data stores or compute services to an Azure data factory.
trans-unit.target: Linked services link data stores or compute services to an Azure data factory.

trans-unit.source: A data store can be an Azure Storage, Azure SQL Database or an on-premises SQL Server database.
trans-unit.target: A data store can be an Azure Storage, Azure SQL Database or an on-premises SQL Server database.

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will create two linked services: StorageLinkedService and AzureSqlLinkedService.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will create two linked services: StorageLinkedService and AzureSqlLinkedService.

trans-unit.source: StorageLinkedService linked service links an Azure Storage Account and AzureSqlLinkedService links an Azure SQL database to the ADFTutorialDataFactory.
trans-unit.target: StorageLinkedService linked service links an Azure Storage Account and AzureSqlLinkedService links an Azure SQL database to the ADFTutorialDataFactory.

trans-unit.source: You will create a pipeline later in this tutorial that copies data from a blob container in StorageLinkedService to a SQL table in AzureSqlLinkedService.
trans-unit.target: You will create a pipeline later in this tutorial that copies data from a blob container in StorageLinkedService to a SQL table in AzureSqlLinkedService.

trans-unit.source: Create a linked service for the Azure storage account
trans-unit.target: Create a linked service for the Azure storage account

trans-unit.source: In the DATA FACTORY blade, click Author and deploy tile to launch the Editor for the data factory.
trans-unit.target: In the DATA FACTORY blade, click Author and deploy tile to launch the Editor for the data factory.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Author and Deploy Tile</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Author and Deploy Tile</linkText>

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Data Factory Editor[data-factory-editor]</linkText><title></title></link> topic for detailed overview of the Data Factory editor.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Data Factory Editor[data-factory-editor]</linkText><title></title></link> topic for detailed overview of the Data Factory editor.

trans-unit.source: In the Editor, click New data store button on the toolbar and select Azure storage from the drop down menu.
trans-unit.target: In the Editor, click New data store button on the toolbar and select Azure storage from the drop down menu.

trans-unit.source: You should see the JSON template for creating an Azure storage linked service in the right pane.
trans-unit.target: You should see the JSON template for creating an Azure storage linked service in the right pane.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Editor New data store button</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Editor New data store button</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Replace accountname and accountkey with the account name and account key values for your Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: Replace accountname and accountkey with the account name and account key values for your Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Editor Blob Storage JSON</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Editor Blob Storage JSON</linkText>

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>JSON Scripting Reference</linkText><title></title></link> for details about JSON properties.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>JSON Scripting Reference</linkText><title></title></link> for details about JSON properties.

trans-unit.source: Click Deploy on the toolbar to deploy the StorageLinkedService.
trans-unit.target: Click Deploy on the toolbar to deploy the StorageLinkedService.

trans-unit.source: Confirm that you see the message LINKED SERVICE CREATED SUCCESSFULLY on the title bar.
trans-unit.target: Confirm that you see the message LINKED SERVICE CREATED SUCCESSFULLY on the title bar.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Editor Blob Storage Deploy</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Editor Blob Storage Deploy</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Create a linked service for the Azure SQL Database
trans-unit.target: Create a linked service for the Azure SQL Database

trans-unit.source: In the Data Factory Editor , click New data store button on the toolbar and select Azure SQL database from the drop down menu.
trans-unit.target: In the Data Factory Editor , click New data store button on the toolbar and select Azure SQL database from the drop down menu.

trans-unit.source: You should see the JSON template for creating the Azure SQL linked service in the right pane.
trans-unit.target: You should see the JSON template for creating the Azure SQL linked service in the right pane.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Editr Azure SQL Settings</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Editr Azure SQL Settings</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Replace servername, databasename, username@servername, and password with names of your Azure SQL server, database, user account, and password.
trans-unit.target: Replace servername, databasename, username@servername, and password with names of your Azure SQL server, database, user account, and password.

trans-unit.source: Click Deploy on the toolbar to create and deploy the AzureSqlLinkedService.
trans-unit.target: Click Deploy on the toolbar to create and deploy the AzureSqlLinkedService.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 3: Create input and output tables
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 3: Create input and output tables

trans-unit.source: In the previous step, you created linked services StorageLinkedService and AzureSqlLinkedService to link an Azure Storage account and Azure SQL database to the data factory: ADFTutorialDataFactory.
trans-unit.target: In the previous step, you created linked services StorageLinkedService and AzureSqlLinkedService to link an Azure Storage account and Azure SQL database to the data factory: ADFTutorialDataFactory.

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will define two data factory tables -- EmpTableFromBlob and EmpSQLTable -- that represent the input/output data that is stored in the data stores referred by StorageLinkedService and AzureSqlLinkedService respectively.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will define two data factory tables -- EmpTableFromBlob and EmpSQLTable -- that represent the input/output data that is stored in the data stores referred by StorageLinkedService and AzureSqlLinkedService respectively.

trans-unit.source: For EmpTableFromBlob, you will specify the blob container that contains a blob with the source data and for EmpSQLTable, you will specify the SQL table that will store the output data.
trans-unit.target: For EmpTableFromBlob, you will specify the blob container that contains a blob with the source data and for EmpSQLTable, you will specify the SQL table that will store the output data.

trans-unit.source: Create input table
trans-unit.target: Create input table

trans-unit.source: A table is a rectangular dataset and has a schema.
trans-unit.target: A table is a rectangular dataset and has a schema.

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will create a table named EmpBlobTable that points to a blob container in the Azure Storage represented by the StorageLinkedService linked service.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will create a table named EmpBlobTable that points to a blob container in the Azure Storage represented by the StorageLinkedService linked service.

trans-unit.source: In the Editor for the Data Factory, click New dataset button on the toolbar and click Blob table from the drop down menu.
trans-unit.target: In the Editor for the Data Factory, click New dataset button on the toolbar and click Blob table from the drop down menu.

trans-unit.source: Replace JSON in the right pane with the following JSON snippet:
trans-unit.target: Replace JSON in the right pane with the following JSON snippet:

trans-unit.source: Note the following:
trans-unit.target: Note the following:

trans-unit.source: dataset type is set to AzureBlob.
trans-unit.target: dataset type is set to AzureBlob.

trans-unit.source: linkedServiceName is set to StorageLinkedService.
trans-unit.target: linkedServiceName is set to StorageLinkedService.

trans-unit.source: You had created this linked service in Step 2.
trans-unit.target: You had created this linked service in Step 2.

trans-unit.source: folderPath is set to the adftutorial container.
trans-unit.target: folderPath is set to the adftutorial container.

trans-unit.source: You can also specify the name of a blob within the folder.
trans-unit.target: You can also specify the name of a blob within the folder.

trans-unit.source: Since you are not specifying the name of the blob, data from all blobs in the container is considered as an input data.
trans-unit.target: Since you are not specifying the name of the blob, data from all blobs in the container is considered as an input data.

trans-unit.source: format type is set to TextFormat
trans-unit.target: format type is set to TextFormat

trans-unit.source: There are two fields in the text file – FirstName and LastName – separated by a comma character (columnDelimiter)
trans-unit.target: There are two fields in the text file – FirstName and LastName – separated by a comma character (columnDelimiter)

trans-unit.source: The availability is set to hourly (frequency is set to hour and interval is set to 1 ), so the Data Factory service will look for input data every hour in the root folder in the blob container (adftutorial) you specified.
trans-unit.target: The availability is set to hourly (frequency is set to hour and interval is set to 1 ), so the Data Factory service will look for input data every hour in the root folder in the blob container (adftutorial) you specified.

trans-unit.source: if you don't specify a fileName for an input table, all files/blobs from the input folder (folderPath) are considered as inputs.
trans-unit.target: if you don't specify a fileName for an input table, all files/blobs from the input folder (folderPath) are considered as inputs.

trans-unit.source: If you specify a fileName in the JSON, only the specified file/blob is considered asn input.
trans-unit.target: If you specify a fileName in the JSON, only the specified file/blob is considered asn input.

trans-unit.source: See the sample files in the <link><linkText>tutorial[adf-tutorial]</linkText><title></title></link> for examples.
trans-unit.target: See the sample files in the <link><linkText>tutorial[adf-tutorial]</linkText><title></title></link> for examples.

trans-unit.source: If you do not specify a fileName for an output table, the generated files in the folderPath are named in the following format: Data..txt (example: Data.0a405f8a-93ff-4c6f-b3be-f69616f1df7a.txt.).
trans-unit.target: If you do not specify a fileName for an output table, the generated files in the folderPath are named in the following format: Data..txt (example: Data.0a405f8a-93ff-4c6f-b3be-f69616f1df7a.txt.).

trans-unit.source: To set folderPath and fileName dynamically based on the SliceStart time, use the partitionedBy property.
trans-unit.target: To set folderPath and fileName dynamically based on the SliceStart time, use the partitionedBy property.

trans-unit.source: In the following example, folderPath uses Year, Month, and Day from from the SliceStart (start time of the slice being processed) and fileName uses Hour from the SliceStart.
trans-unit.target: In the following example, folderPath uses Year, Month, and Day from from the SliceStart (start time of the slice being processed) and fileName uses Hour from the SliceStart.

trans-unit.source: For example, if a slice is being produced for 2014-10-20T08:00:00, the folderName is set to wikidatagateway/wikisampledataout/2014/10/20 and the fileName is set to 08.csv.
trans-unit.target: For example, if a slice is being produced for 2014-10-20T08:00:00, the folderName is set to wikidatagateway/wikisampledataout/2014/10/20 and the fileName is set to 08.csv.

trans-unit.source: "folderPath": "wikidatagateway/wikisampledataout/{Year}/{Month}/{Day}",
trans-unit.target: "folderPath": "wikidatagateway/wikisampledataout/{Year}/{Month}/{Day}",

trans-unit.source: "fileName": "{Hour}.csv",
trans-unit.target: "fileName": "{Hour}.csv",

trans-unit.source: "partitionedBy":
trans-unit.target: "partitionedBy":

trans-unit.source: { "name": "Year", "value": { "type": "DateTime", "date": "SliceStart", "format": "yyyy" } },
trans-unit.target: { "name": "Year", "value": { "type": "DateTime", "date": "SliceStart", "format": "yyyy" } },

trans-unit.source: { "name": "Month", "value": { "type": "DateTime", "date": "SliceStart", "format": "MM" } },
trans-unit.target: { "name": "Month", "value": { "type": "DateTime", "date": "SliceStart", "format": "MM" } },

trans-unit.source: { "name": "Day", "value": { "type": "DateTime", "date": "SliceStart", "format": "dd" } },
trans-unit.target: { "name": "Day", "value": { "type": "DateTime", "date": "SliceStart", "format": "dd" } },

trans-unit.source: { "name": "Hour", "value": { "type": "DateTime", "date": "SliceStart", "format": "hh" } }
trans-unit.target: { "name": "Hour", "value": { "type": "DateTime", "date": "SliceStart", "format": "hh" } }

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>JSON Scripting Reference</linkText><title></title></link> for details about JSON properties.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>JSON Scripting Reference</linkText><title></title></link> for details about JSON properties.

trans-unit.source: Click Deploy on the toolbar to create and deploy the EmpTableFromBlob table.
trans-unit.target: Click Deploy on the toolbar to create and deploy the EmpTableFromBlob table.

trans-unit.source: Confirm that you see the TABLE CREATED SUCCESSFULLY message on the title bar of the Editor.
trans-unit.target: Confirm that you see the TABLE CREATED SUCCESSFULLY message on the title bar of the Editor.

trans-unit.source: Create output table
trans-unit.target: Create output table

trans-unit.source: In this part of the step, you will create an output table named EmpSQLTable that points to a SQL table in the Azure SQL database that is represented by the AzureSqlLinkedService linked service.
trans-unit.target: In this part of the step, you will create an output table named EmpSQLTable that points to a SQL table in the Azure SQL database that is represented by the AzureSqlLinkedService linked service.

trans-unit.source: In the Editor for the Data Factory, click New dataset button on the toolbar and click Azure SQL table from the drop down menu.
trans-unit.target: In the Editor for the Data Factory, click New dataset button on the toolbar and click Azure SQL table from the drop down menu.

trans-unit.source: Replace JSON in the right pane with the following JSON snippet:
trans-unit.target: Replace JSON in the right pane with the following JSON snippet:

trans-unit.source: Note the following:
trans-unit.target: Note the following:

trans-unit.source: dataset type is set to AzureSQLTable.
trans-unit.target: dataset type is set to AzureSQLTable.

trans-unit.source: linkedServiceName is set to AzureSqlLinkedService (you had created this linked service in Step 2).
trans-unit.target: linkedServiceName is set to AzureSqlLinkedService (you had created this linked service in Step 2).

trans-unit.source: tablename is set to emp.
trans-unit.target: tablename is set to emp.

trans-unit.source: There are three columns – ID, FirstName, and LastName – in the emp table in the database, but ID is an identity column, so you need to specify only FirstName and LastName here.
trans-unit.target: There are three columns – ID, FirstName, and LastName – in the emp table in the database, but ID is an identity column, so you need to specify only FirstName and LastName here.

trans-unit.source: The availability is set to hourly (frequency set to hour and interval set to 1).
trans-unit.target: The availability is set to hourly (frequency set to hour and interval set to 1).

trans-unit.source: The Data Factory service will generate an output data slice every hour in the emp table in the Azure SQL database.
trans-unit.target: The Data Factory service will generate an output data slice every hour in the emp table in the Azure SQL database.

trans-unit.source: Click Deploy on the toolbar to create and deploy the EmpSQLTable table.
trans-unit.target: Click Deploy on the toolbar to create and deploy the EmpSQLTable table.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 4: Create and run a pipeline
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 4: Create and run a pipeline

trans-unit.source: In this step, you create a pipeline with a Copy Activity that uses EmpTableFromBlob as input and EmpSQLTable as output.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you create a pipeline with a Copy Activity that uses EmpTableFromBlob as input and EmpSQLTable as output.

trans-unit.source: In the Editor for the Data Factory, click New pipeline button on the toolbar.
trans-unit.target: In the Editor for the Data Factory, click New pipeline button on the toolbar.

trans-unit.source: Click ... (Ellipsis) on the toolbar if you do not see the button.
trans-unit.target: Click ... (Ellipsis) on the toolbar if you do not see the button.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can right-click Pipelines in the tree view and click New pipeline.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can right-click Pipelines in the tree view and click New pipeline.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Editor New Pipeline Button</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Editor New Pipeline Button</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Replace JSON in the right pane with the following JSON snippet:
trans-unit.target: Replace JSON in the right pane with the following JSON snippet:

trans-unit.source: Note the following:
trans-unit.target: Note the following:

trans-unit.source: In the activities section, there is only one activity whose type is set to CopyActivity.
trans-unit.target: In the activities section, there is only one activity whose type is set to CopyActivity.

trans-unit.source: Input for the activity is set to EmpTableFromBlob and output for the activity is set to EmpSQLTable.
trans-unit.target: Input for the activity is set to EmpTableFromBlob and output for the activity is set to EmpSQLTable.

trans-unit.source: In the transformation section, BlobSource is specified as the source type and SqlSink is specified as the sink type.
trans-unit.target: In the transformation section, BlobSource is specified as the source type and SqlSink is specified as the sink type.

trans-unit.source: Replace the value of the start property with the current day and end value with the next day.
trans-unit.target: Replace the value of the start property with the current day and end value with the next day.

trans-unit.source: You can specify only the date part and skip the time part of the date time.
trans-unit.target: You can specify only the date part and skip the time part of the date time.

trans-unit.source: For example, "2015-02-03", which is equivalent to "2015-02-03T00:00:00Z"
trans-unit.target: For example, "2015-02-03", which is equivalent to "2015-02-03T00:00:00Z"

trans-unit.source: Both start and end datetimes must be in <link><linkText>ISO format</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Both start and end datetimes must be in <link><linkText>ISO format</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The end time is optional, but we will use it in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: The end time is optional, but we will use it in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: If you do not specify value for the end property, it is calculated as "start + 48 hours".
trans-unit.target: If you do not specify value for the end property, it is calculated as "start + 48 hours".

trans-unit.source: To run the pipeline indefinitely, specify 9999-09-09 as the value for the end property.
trans-unit.target: To run the pipeline indefinitely, specify 9999-09-09 as the value for the end property.

trans-unit.source: In the example above, there will be 24 data slices as each data slice is produced hourly.
trans-unit.target: In the example above, there will be 24 data slices as each data slice is produced hourly.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>JSON Scripting Reference</linkText><title></title></link> for details about JSON properties.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>JSON Scripting Reference</linkText><title></title></link> for details about JSON properties.

trans-unit.source: Click Deploy on the toolbar to create and deploy the ADFTutorialPipeline.
trans-unit.target: Click Deploy on the toolbar to create and deploy the ADFTutorialPipeline.

trans-unit.source: Confirm that you see the PIPELINE CREATED SUCCESSFULLY message.
trans-unit.target: Confirm that you see the PIPELINE CREATED SUCCESSFULLY message.

trans-unit.source: Now, close the Editor blade by clicking X.
trans-unit.target: Now, close the Editor blade by clicking X.

trans-unit.source: Click X again to close the ADFTutorialDataFactory blade with the toolbar and tree view.
trans-unit.target: Click X again to close the ADFTutorialDataFactory blade with the toolbar and tree view.

trans-unit.source: If you see your unsaved edits will be discarded message, click OK.
trans-unit.target: If you see your unsaved edits will be discarded message, click OK.

trans-unit.source: You should be back to the DATA FACTORY blade for the ADFTutorialDataFactory.
trans-unit.target: You should be back to the DATA FACTORY blade for the ADFTutorialDataFactory.

trans-unit.source: Congratulations! You have successfully created an Azure data factory, linked services, tables, and a pipeline and scheduled the pipeline.
trans-unit.target: Congratulations! You have successfully created an Azure data factory, linked services, tables, and a pipeline and scheduled the pipeline.

trans-unit.source: View the data factory in a Diagram View
trans-unit.target: View the data factory in a Diagram View

trans-unit.source: In the DATA FACTORY blade, click Diagram.
trans-unit.target: In the DATA FACTORY blade, click Diagram.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Data Factory Blade - Diagram Tile</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Data Factory Blade - Diagram Tile</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You should see the diagram similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: You should see the diagram similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Diagram view</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Diagram view</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can zoom in, zoom out, zoom to 100%, zoom to fit, automatically position pipelines and tables, and show lineage information (highlights upstream and downstream items of selected items).
trans-unit.target: You can zoom in, zoom out, zoom to 100%, zoom to fit, automatically position pipelines and tables, and show lineage information (highlights upstream and downstream items of selected items).

trans-unit.source: You can double-blick on an object (input/output table or pipeline) to see properties for it.
trans-unit.target: You can double-blick on an object (input/output table or pipeline) to see properties for it.

trans-unit.source: Right-click on ADFTutorialPipeline in the Diagram View and click Open pipeline.
trans-unit.target: Right-click on ADFTutorialPipeline in the Diagram View and click Open pipeline.

trans-unit.source: You should see the activities in the pipeline along with input and output datasets for the activities.
trans-unit.target: You should see the activities in the pipeline along with input and output datasets for the activities.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you have only one activity in the pipeline (Copy Activity) with EmpTableBlob as input dataset and EmpSQLTable as output dataset.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you have only one activity in the pipeline (Copy Activity) with EmpTableBlob as input dataset and EmpSQLTable as output dataset.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Open Pipeline</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Open Pipeline</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Data factory in the breadcrumb in the top-left corner to get back to the diagram view.
trans-unit.target: Click Data factory in the breadcrumb in the top-left corner to get back to the diagram view.

trans-unit.source: The diagram view displays all the pipelines.
trans-unit.target: The diagram view displays all the pipelines.

trans-unit.source: In this example, you have only created one pipeline.
trans-unit.target: In this example, you have only created one pipeline.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Step 5: Monitor the datasets and pipeline
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Step 5: Monitor the datasets and pipeline

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will use the Azure Portal to monitor what’s going on in an Azure data factory.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will use the Azure Portal to monitor what’s going on in an Azure data factory.

trans-unit.source: You can also use PowerShell cmdlets to monitor datasets and pipelines.
trans-unit.target: You can also use PowerShell cmdlets to monitor datasets and pipelines.

trans-unit.source: For details about using cmdlets for monitoring, see <link><linkText>Monitor and Manage Data Factory using PowerShell Cmdlets[monitor-manage-using-powershell]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For details about using cmdlets for monitoring, see <link><linkText>Monitor and Manage Data Factory using PowerShell Cmdlets[monitor-manage-using-powershell]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to <link><linkText>Azure Portal (Preview)[azure-preview-portal]</linkText><title></title></link> if you don't have it open.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to <link><linkText>Azure Portal (Preview)[azure-preview-portal]</linkText><title></title></link> if you don't have it open.

trans-unit.source: If the blade for ADFTutorialDataFactory is not open, open it by clicking ADFTutorialDataFactory on the Startboard.
trans-unit.target: If the blade for ADFTutorialDataFactory is not open, open it by clicking ADFTutorialDataFactory on the Startboard.

trans-unit.source: You should see the count and names of tables and pipeline you created on this blade.
trans-unit.target: You should see the count and names of tables and pipeline you created on this blade.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>home page with names</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>home page with names</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Now, click Datasets tile.
trans-unit.target: Now, click Datasets tile.

trans-unit.source: In the Datasets blade, click EmpTableFromBlob.
trans-unit.target: In the Datasets blade, click EmpTableFromBlob.

trans-unit.source: This is the input table for the ADFTutorialPipeline.
trans-unit.target: This is the input table for the ADFTutorialPipeline.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Datasets with EmpTableFromBlob selected</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Datasets with EmpTableFromBlob selected</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Notice that the data slices up to the current time have already been produced and they are Ready because the emp.txt file exists all the time in the blob container: adftutorial\input.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the data slices up to the current time have already been produced and they are Ready because the emp.txt file exists all the time in the blob container: adftutorial\input.

trans-unit.source: Confirm that no slices show up in the Recently failed slices section at the bottom.
trans-unit.target: Confirm that no slices show up in the Recently failed slices section at the bottom.

trans-unit.source: Both Recently updated slices and Recently failed slices lists are sorted by the LAST UPDATE TIME.
trans-unit.target: Both Recently updated slices and Recently failed slices lists are sorted by the LAST UPDATE TIME.

trans-unit.source: The update time of a slice is changed in the following situations.
trans-unit.target: The update time of a slice is changed in the following situations.

trans-unit.source: You update the status of the slice manually, for example, by using the Set-AzureDataFactorySliceStatus (or) by clicking RUN on the SLICE blade for the slice.
trans-unit.target: You update the status of the slice manually, for example, by using the Set-AzureDataFactorySliceStatus (or) by clicking RUN on the SLICE blade for the slice.

trans-unit.source: The slice changes status due to an execution (e.g. a run started, a run ended and failed, a run ended and succeeded, etc).
trans-unit.target: The slice changes status due to an execution (e.g. a run started, a run ended and failed, a run ended and succeeded, etc).

trans-unit.source: Click on the title of the lists or ... (ellipses) to see the larger list of slices.
trans-unit.target: Click on the title of the lists or ... (ellipses) to see the larger list of slices.

trans-unit.source: Click Filter on the toolbar to filter the slices.
trans-unit.target: Click Filter on the toolbar to filter the slices.

trans-unit.source: To view the data slices sorted by the slice start/end times instead, click Data slices (by slice time) tile.
trans-unit.target: To view the data slices sorted by the slice start/end times instead, click Data slices (by slice time) tile.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Data Slices by Slice Time</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Data Slices by Slice Time</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Now, in the Datasets blade, click the EmpSQLTable.
trans-unit.target: Now, in the Datasets blade, click the EmpSQLTable.

trans-unit.source: This is the output table for the ADFTutorialPipeline.
trans-unit.target: This is the output table for the ADFTutorialPipeline.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>data sets blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>data sets blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You should see the EmpSQLTable blade as shown below:
trans-unit.target: You should see the EmpSQLTable blade as shown below:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>table blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>table blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Notice that the data slices up to the current time have already been produced and they are Ready.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the data slices up to the current time have already been produced and they are Ready.

trans-unit.source: No slices show up in the Problem slices section at the bottom.
trans-unit.target: No slices show up in the Problem slices section at the bottom.

trans-unit.source: Click **…
trans-unit.target: Click **…

trans-unit.source: (Ellipsis)** to see all the slices.
trans-unit.target: (Ellipsis)** to see all the slices.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>data slices blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>data slices blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click on any data slice from the list and you should see the DATA SLICE blade.
trans-unit.target: Click on any data slice from the list and you should see the DATA SLICE blade.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>data slice blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>data slice blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If the slice is not in the Ready state, you can see the upstream slices that are not Ready and are blocking the current slice from executing in the Upstream slices that are not ready list.
trans-unit.target: If the slice is not in the Ready state, you can see the upstream slices that are not Ready and are blocking the current slice from executing in the Upstream slices that are not ready list.

trans-unit.source: In the DATA SLICE blade, you should see all activity runs in the list at the bottom.
trans-unit.target: In the DATA SLICE blade, you should see all activity runs in the list at the bottom.

trans-unit.source: Click on an activity run to see the ACTIVITY RUN DETAILS blade.
trans-unit.target: Click on an activity run to see the ACTIVITY RUN DETAILS blade.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Activity Run Details</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Activity Run Details</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click X to close all the blades until you get back to the home blade for the ADFTutorialDataFactory.
trans-unit.target: Click X to close all the blades until you get back to the home blade for the ADFTutorialDataFactory.

trans-unit.source: (optional) Click Pipelines on the home page for ADFTutorialDataFactory, click ADFTutorialPipeline in the Pipelines blade, and drill through input tables (Consumed) or output tables (Produced).
trans-unit.target: (optional) Click Pipelines on the home page for ADFTutorialDataFactory, click ADFTutorialPipeline in the Pipelines blade, and drill through input tables (Consumed) or output tables (Produced).

trans-unit.source: Launch SQL Server Management Studio, connect to the Azure SQL Database, and verify that the rows are inserted into the emp table in the database.
trans-unit.target: Launch SQL Server Management Studio, connect to the Azure SQL Database, and verify that the rows are inserted into the emp table in the database.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>sql query results</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>sql query results</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Summary
trans-unit.target: Summary

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you created an Azure data factory to copy data from an Azure blob to an Azure SQL database.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you created an Azure data factory to copy data from an Azure blob to an Azure SQL database.

trans-unit.source: You used the Azure Preview Portal to create the data factory, linked services, tables, and a pipeline.
trans-unit.target: You used the Azure Preview Portal to create the data factory, linked services, tables, and a pipeline.

trans-unit.source: Here are the high level steps you performed in this tutorial:
trans-unit.target: Here are the high level steps you performed in this tutorial:

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure data factory.
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure data factory.

trans-unit.source: Create linked services that link data stores and computes (referred as Linked Services) to the data factory.
trans-unit.target: Create linked services that link data stores and computes (referred as Linked Services) to the data factory.

trans-unit.source: Create tables which describe input data and output data for pipelines.
trans-unit.target: Create tables which describe input data and output data for pipelines.

trans-unit.source: Create pipelines.
trans-unit.target: Create pipelines.

trans-unit.source: A pipeline consists of one or more activities and processes the inputs and produces outputs.
trans-unit.target: A pipeline consists of one or more activities and processes the inputs and produces outputs.

trans-unit.source: Set the active period for the pipeline by specifying Start time and End time for the pipeline.
trans-unit.target: Set the active period for the pipeline by specifying Start time and End time for the pipeline.

trans-unit.source: The active period defines the time duration in which data slices will be produced.
trans-unit.target: The active period defines the time duration in which data slices will be produced.

trans-unit.source: For a list of supported activities, see <link><linkText>Pipelines and Activities[msdn-activities]</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: For a list of supported activities, see <link><linkText>Pipelines and Activities[msdn-activities]</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: topic and for a list of supported linked services, see <link><linkText>Linked Services[msdn-linkedservices]</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: topic and for a list of supported linked services, see <link><linkText>Linked Services[msdn-linkedservices]</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: topic on MSDN Library.
trans-unit.target: topic on MSDN Library.

trans-unit.source: To do this tutorial using Azure PowerShell, see <link><linkText>Create and monitor a data factory using Azure PowerShell[monitor-manage-using-powershell]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To do this tutorial using Azure PowerShell, see <link><linkText>Create and monitor a data factory using Azure PowerShell[monitor-manage-using-powershell]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.target: Send Feedback

trans-unit.target: We would really appreciate your feedback on this article.
